text:
Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, showing the Columbus Memorial Arch, tricentennial celebration of the discovery of America.

1892.

Charles L. Ritzman.

Neg #2602.

Christopher Columbus Memorial Arch, Fifth Avenue,
1892.
August Loeffler, Photographer,
from P.L. Sperr,eollection.

kc 15:

Central Park: The Circle at 59th Street and Fifth Ave., showing this entrance to the southeastern corner of the Park. Technically
this is a portion of the Grand Army Plaza.
About 1895.
Ewing Galloway.

Fifth Avenue,West side from north of West 59th Street, looking southwards. The Vanderbilt mansion may be seen across Plaza Square on the South West corner of W.59th Street, and looking southwards on the Avenue,the spires may be seen
of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.
About 1900.
Urbrock Collection,
Credit line Imperative.

Fifth Avenue,West side from north of West 59th Street, looking southwards. The Vanderbilt mansion may be seen across Plaza Square on the South West corner of W.59th Street, and looking southwards on the Avenue,the spires may be seen
of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.
About 1900.
Urbrock Collection,
Credit line Imperative.

Fifth Avenue, north from 59th Street, Central Park Zoo is in
the centre.
Ewing Galloway  about 1910
Ne( ~7w7

(1)
Central Park: A view of the southeastern entrance to the Park, with the equestrian statue of General Sherman at the N. W. corner of 59th Street ( foreground ),at 5th Avenue. The buildings shown on the extreme right are
on the east side of the Avenue.
May 12, 1910.
Walter L. Bogert.
(2)
The same, at a later date. Note the change of the Fifth Ave. outline. The horse drawn carriage is a local feature of this vicinity.
August 4, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, as No. 2 from a view point slightly southward and showing in the foreground a portion of the Fountain of Abundance. in the Grand Army
Plasa, which is not a part of the park.
Auguat 4, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

22-24 West 59th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, showing two old apartment houses, long neglected, which adjoin the Plaza Hotel.
About 1922.
Brown Brothers.

Hotel Netherland, Fifth Avenue at N.E. corner of 59th Street. Demolished in 1927 for construction of Hotel Savoy-Plaza.
About 1923.

The Hotel Netherland was demolished for the Sherry-Netherland Hotel, not the Savoy-Plaza

(1)
Central Park: A pathway and trees in the southern part of the park; the view is south towards the Plaza Hotel.
1923.
P.L. Sperr.
(2)
Slightly eastward to show through the trees the Hotel Netherland on Fifth Ave. and 59th Street.
1923.
P.L. Sperr.

(1)
Central Park: A pathway and trees in the southern part of the park; the view is south towards the Plaza Hotel.
1923.
P.L. Sperr.
(2)
Slightly eastward to show through the trees the Hotel Netherland on Fifth Ave. and 59th Street.
1923.
P.L. Sperr.

South on Fifth Avenue from 59th Street, showing Pulitzer Fountain at Plaza and Vanderbilt Chateau, Fifth Avenue, west side 57th to 58th Streets.
About 1923.

Celebrations, Parades, and Municipal Events: Parade (Unknown) passing the Sherman statue on Fifth Avenue at 59th Street. (Mount No. 1). A set of 3 views showing marching contingents moving southward on the Avenue to be reviewed from stand at the Sherman Monument. The latter is to the S.E. corner of Central Park and is technically located in a small plot that officially is the Grand Army Plaza. Massed groups to the right are lining the east side of Fifth Avenue, north of 59th Street (crosstown car thereupon).

Prior to 1924
Views: 1-2-3
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Miscellaneous.

title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Miscellaneous.

text:
Celebrations, Parades, and Municipal Events: Parade (unknown) passing the Sherman Statue on Fifth Avenue at 59th Street. (Mount 2). Four views photographed in a northward direction up the Avenue to show details of a parade moving southward on same. The car tracks see are of the crosstown line at 59th Street. The other two views are below this point and one sees a portion of the old Hotel Savoy at the S.E. corner of 59th Street. This structure, demolished in 1924 and replaced with the modern Savoy-Plaza Hotel, dates these photos.

Prior to 1924
Views: 1-2-3-4
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Miscellaneous.

text:
Savoy Hotel, S.E. corner of Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, now
demolished.
June, 1925.

(1)
Central Park South, west from Fifth Ave., to Columbus Circle, showing buildings that face the southern edge of Central Park. At the left is the Plaza Hotel; in the center, on the S.E. corner of Sixth Ave., is the New York Athletic Club, and beyond it, though dimly
visible, are the Spanish Flats.
December 1925.
Brown Brothers.
(2)
A similar view from the northern half of the Grand Army Plaza, showing the change in the building outline; prominent of which are the
St. Moritn Hotel and the Essex House.
August 4, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

South on Fifth Avenue from 59th Street, showing Plaza.
At extreme right is Plaza Hotel. Vanderbilt Mansion and Heckscher Building in center foreground.
About 1925.
Photograph by Ewing Galloway.

Fire which destroyed scaffolding on tower of incomplete Sherry- Netherland Hotel, Fifth Avenue at N.E. corner of 59th Street. No damage was done to the structure itself.
April 12, 1927.
International News Photograph

North on Fifth Avenue from 59th Street. Note hack stand for horse-carriages. In this section today (1935) there are a great many horse-drawn hacks.

May 6 1928

P.L. Sperr, photographer

NO REPRODUCTIONS

59th Street (Central Park South), south side, from Sixth to Fifth Avenues. At the right, on the S.E. corner of Sixth Avenue, is the old New York Athletic Club. This will soon be demolished and a new building erected on the S.E. corner of Seventh Avenue and 59th Street. At the left are the hotels Plaza and Savoy-Plaza.
May 25, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

Central Park, Miscellaneous: A set of 2 views showing a demonstration of foresters safety equipment in the southeastern corner of the Park. Buildings shown(from left to right) at Fifth Ave. and 59th Street are the Sherry Netherland, the Savoy-Plaza, the Squibb Building and the
Plaza Hotel.
About 1930.
A. L. Schussler.

Central Park, Miscellaneous: A set of 2 views showing a demonstration of foresters safety equipment in the southeastern corner of the Park. Buildings shown(from left to right) at Fifth Ave. and 59th Street are the Sherry Netherland, the Savoy-Plaza, the Squibb Building and the
Plaza Hotel.
About 1930.
A. L. Schussler.

Central Park: The southern edge of same as viewed in a southward direction and showing the apartment ridge on Central Park South (West 59th Street) from Fifth Ave. (left) to Columbus Circle (right, not shown). Note in the center background, the Chrysler Building under construction.
1930.
Ewing Galloway.

(1)
Central Park: The Lake, a view south southeast, towards 59th Street west of FiYth Avenue. In the middle of the picture the tower of the Chrysler Building rises above the Hotel Plaza.
JV1Y 12, 1V31.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, another view, taken from the western side of the
willow tree in the foreground.
July 12, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, four years later. The gigantic bulk of the R. C. A. Building, in Radio City, has been added to the skyline.
June 24, 1935.

(1)

Central Park: An eastward view to Fifth Ave., across the southern edge of the Park. Buildings on the right are on the south side of Central
Park South (West 59th Street), east from Columbus Circle.
About 1931.
Ewing Galloway.

Fifth Avenue, south, from 59th Street, showing Bergdorf-Goodman  department store on site of old Vanderbilt Mansion. Savoy-Plaza on extreme left, Plaza Hotel on extreme right. About 1932. Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

West 59th Street, at Fifth Avenue (shown on the left), showing several open barouches at the Grand Army Plaza. On the left appears buildings on the east side of Fifth Avenue, south from but not including East 59th Street, to and including East 57th Street, showing on the extreme left margin a portion of the Savoy-Plaza Hotel. Across the truck appears the female figurine atop the Pulitzer Memorial. No. 1 is an enlargement made by the photographer; No. 2 being a copv
of the original negative bv the N.Y.P.L.
About 1936.
Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad A.R.P.S.

Central Park: . Night scene across the southeastern corner of the Park, showing buildings on Fifth Avenue at 59th Street, reflected in the Boat Lake. Prominent of these are, the Hotel Pierre, the Savoy-Plaza, the Hotel Sherry-Netherland and the Squibb Building. No.1 is an enlargement made by the photographer: No. 2 being a copy made by the N.Y.P.L.
About 1936.
Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad F.R.P.S.

Central Park South, east from and including Seventh to Fifth Aves. Shown in the foreground and in the order of their appearance, are the N.Y. Athletic Club (No. 130-, Essex House (Nos. 170-1604, Hampshire House (No. 150) Centre Ass'n (No. 120) Navarro (No. 112), Barbizon Plaza (No. 106-100), St. Moritn (No. 56) and the Sherry Netherland Hotel (N.E. corner of 59th Street and Fifth Ave).  Central Park forms the north side of this street, which
technically should be West 59th Street.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

Fifth Avenue, as viewed southward from the Central Park Zoo, showing the building outline at that point. the Sherry-Netherland Hotel tower is obscuring the Savoy-Plaza and the Squibb Building. Note the chanticleer atop the weathervane on the Heckscher Building.

About 1937.

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad A.H.P.S.

CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE

(1)
Recreations and hobbies, miscellaneous: Children eating a bit of lunch during dips.in the water at the foot of the Fountain of Abundance. in the Grand Army Plaza on Fifth Ave., at 59th Street. Buildings shown
on the right line the east side of same, northward.
August 4, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same in a northwestward direction with the southern edge of
Central Park forming a background.
August 4, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Recreation and hobbies - Miscellaneous - Children.

text:
Central Park: A set of 2 views of the Pond, located in the South East corner, as viewed in that direction to show above same buildings on Fifth Avenue at 59th Street. From left to right they are the Hotel Pierre, Ritz Tower, Sherry-Netherland, Savoy-Plaza,
Squibbs Bldg. and the Plaza.
April 23, 1938.
Views 1 and 2
P. L. Sperr,

Central Park: A set of 2 views of the Pond, located in the South East corner, as viewed in that direction to show above same buildings on Fifth Avenue at 59th Street. From left to right they are the Hotel Pierre, Ritz Tower, Sherry-Netherland, Savoy-Plaza,
Squibbs Bldg. and the Plaza.
April 23, 1938.
Views 1 and 2
P. L. Sperr,

folder: Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, Manhattan, N.Y.
text:
Transportation: A horsedrawn open barouche at Central Park (Fifth Avenue and 59th Street). The Hotel Plaza forms a background.
1938-9
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume 'Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.
title: Transportation - Horse-drawn open barouche.

text:
Transportation:  A horse-drawn open barouche at Central Park (Fifth Avenue and 59th Street).  The Hotel Savoy-Plaza and a portion of the Squibb Building form a backdrop.

1938-9

Alexander Alland
title: Transportation - [A horse drawn open barouche in Central Park.]

text: 59th Street at Fifth Avenue, looking east. Hotel Savoy is pictured. Received November 13, 1945. P. L. Sperr Collection.

Hotel Netherland, at center, Fifth Avenue and 59th Street (northeast corner). Savoy Hotel at right, Metropolitan Club at extreme left.

P.L. Sperr collection
Rec'd January 13, 1945

Hotel Netherland (replaced by Sherry-Netherland Hotel in November, 1927) at right, on 59th Street and Fifth Avenue. View looking from Grand Army Plaza east across Fifth Avenue. Buildings to the north of the hotel were replaced by 785 Fifth Avenue, the Park V apartment house, circa 1961.
